articles.headline: Martoma, SAC Capital Ex-Trader, Gets 9 Years in Prison
articles.snippet: Mathew Martoma’s parents asked why his former boss, Steven A. Cohen, was not also charged with insider trading if their son had done something wrong.
articles.abstract: Mathew Martoma’s parents asked why his former boss, Steven A. Cohen, was not also charged with insider trading if their son had done something wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:05 p.m. | The parents of Mathew Martoma, the former portfolio manager for SAC Capital Advisors, sat quietly through his insider trading trial this year. But moments after a federal judge sentenced Mr. Martoma on Monday to nine years in prison for carrying out one of the biggest insider trading schemes on record, his parents could contain themselves no more.

articles.headline: Ukraine Palace Is Still Emblem of Dysfunction
articles.snippet: More than six months after protesters drove Viktor F. Yanukovych from power, his lavish estate displays how difficult it is to bring about a real break with Ukraine’s past.
articles.abstract: More than six months after protesters drove Viktor F. Yanukovych from power, his lavish estate displays how difficult it is to bring about a real break with Ukraine’s past.
articles.lead_paragraph: VYSHOROD, Ukraine — It was supposed to become a Museum of Corruption, a triumphant trophy of Ukraine’s February revolution and a monument to its new leaders’ determination to uproot the lawlessness and avarice that blighted this country’s first two decades as an independent nation.

articles.headline: Amazon Cuts Struggling Phone’s Price to 99 Cents
articles.snippet: Analysts said the drastic cut was inevitable, but wondered if it would help spur sales that have been disappointing so far.
articles.abstract: Analysts said the drastic cut was inevitable, but wondered if it would help spur sales that have been disappointing so far.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sixty thousand people vied to attend the unveiling of Amazon’s first smartphone in late June.

articles.headline: Home Depot Data Breach Could Be the Largest Yet
articles.snippet: Home Depot confirmed on Monday that hackers had attacked its cash register system. Information on more than 60 million credit cards may have been stolen.
articles.abstract: Home Depot confirmed on Monday that hackers had attacked its cash register system. Information on more than 60 million credit cards may have been stolen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home Depot confirmed on Monday that hackers had broken into its in-store payments systems, in what could be the largest known breach of a retail company’s computer network.

articles.headline: Ferguson Sets Broad Change for City Courts
articles.snippet: The City Council plans to approve several changes, including a citizen review board for the police department and a reduction in court fines that have disproportionately affected black residents.
articles.abstract: The City Council plans to approve several changes, including a citizen review board for the police department and a reduction in court fines that have disproportionately affected black residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the first major sign of change in this small city since last month’s police killing of an unarmed black teenager, the Ferguson City Council said Monday that it would establish a citizen review board to provide guidance for the Police Department.

articles.headline: Google Is Target of European Backlash on U.S. Tech Dominance
articles.snippet: Regulators want Google to change its algorithm. If Google doesn’t comply, the settlement it reached with Europe this year may be voided and it will face antitrust charges.
articles.abstract: Regulators want Google to change its algorithm. If Google doesn’t comply, the settlement it reached with Europe this year may be voided and it will face antitrust charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A top German official called for Google to be broken up. A French minister pronounced the company a threat to his country’s sovereignty. A European publishing executive likened it to a Wagnerian dragon.

articles.headline: Shifting Polls in Scotland Send Investors Rushing for Shelter
articles.snippet: A poll showing that Scottish voters for the first time favor independence set off a sharp decline in the British pound and the stocks of financial institutions with large operations in Scotland.
articles.abstract: A poll showing that Scottish voters for the first time favor independence set off a sharp decline in the British pound and the stocks of financial institutions with large operations in Scotland.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scotland, home to just five million people, has never weighed on the minds of currency traders and market investors the way that Russia or China or the eurozone has — until now.

articles.headline: Support in Coca-Cola Vote Depends on How the Math Is Done
articles.snippet: Coke’s assurance of support for a new compensation plan failed to account for opposition by three of the company’s six largest shareholders.
articles.abstract: Coke’s assurance of support for a new compensation plan failed to account for opposition by three of the company’s six largest shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring, in the face of increasing questions about Coca-Cola’s proposed new compensation plan, the chairwoman of the company’s compensation committee, Maria Elena Lagomasino, declared at Coke’s annual meeting, “We are pleased that we are seeing broad-based investor support for this plan.”
